pros: Supportive Team Good working environment

review_title: Great Person-Centred Organisation who Care about people they support and staff
job_title: Area Manager in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: I've been working at United Response now for just over 3 months. I have been in the sector for over 25 years, and i can honestly say that they are a great employer. I have had some great training, opportunities to meet some amazing people. They have great values, and our long-term plans not only strive for better opportunities for the People we support, but the people that work for them. They do thoughtful things such as send out wellbeing boxes for all employees and this year have given an uplift in salaries to our front-line staff because they recognise that times are increasingly difficult. I would recommend them as a great employer.
cons: Some of our processes are a little clunky - But they are working on it.

pros: Great service users and staff
cons: Management could be more involved

pros: Great organisation to work for. I worked for a truly awful company previously and UR have proved to be the polar opposite. Excellent management, pay that has improved considerably, person centered support , the fact you actually feel appreciated....
cons: None worth mentioning other than paperwork systems, however that's set to change in the new year.

pros: flexible, good managment, good training, good hours
cons: no cons really, I enjoy working here

pros: Flexible and stable shifts paid annual leave Paid training and learning sessions including teams meeting
cons: It is located in an area not easily accessible Same salary for both old and new staff No career path

review_title: If you want no life then this is the job for you
pros: Lovely people to support and some staff.
cons: Difficult senior management. High blame culture. No support. End up covering all hours. I became ill.

pros: The pros we really could make a difference to peoples lives in supporting their day to day lives.
cons: I worked here long before 2018 but it’s very relevant and potential employees need to know so where do I start. There was a total lack of leadership. Staff retention was through the roof because they kept firing people once they reached the end of their probation. The reason they let me go was pathetic and I wished I was part of a union back then. I would of taken them to caught. I was asked to look into a holiday for a service user (given no clear deadline) and I was waiting for the person I needed to speak to to come to town as I originally said it as a suggestion. I was never told to book it. I was up for disobeying management. There were no risk assessments done for staff resulting in staff members getting attacked, training was insufficient for what we had to deal with I even mentioned it on more than one occasion even the police were willing to put in a complaint on one occasion. To say I was stitched up is an understatement and I’d advise anyone considering working there to get a good union on your side. Document everything you do and what your management has said to you in meetings and let them know you know your working rights and what the conveniences are for constructive and unfair dismissal is. I wished I could of taken them all the way but I lacked experience and knowledge back then. I have lived with PTSD, anxiety and depression because of what happened to me and I wouldn’t wish that on my worst enemy. I struggle to trust anyone in authority after my experience with this company even though I know they are ok. There were no clear routines on shift since there was no proper induction to the homes you kind of winged it every shift yet relief workers expected you to know what to do.

job_title: Support Worker in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Good loyal staff , good to see progress in the people you support.
cons: No support from management, some managers allowed to move from one service to another wiping out years of hard work by loyal staff.  Lots of long term staff leaving without any senior management asking why.  No leaving interview to find out what the problems are, I could go on with lots of examples but the company obviously don't care. I see previous reviews saying the same, and United response reply saying they could contact HR to discuss ...... Should the company not notice when a service is crumbling when they are putting lots of leavers through from the same service?? Should this not be the time to ask what the problems are??

job_title: Relief Support Worker in Chorley, England
pros:
Priveledge  of supporting vulnerable adults
Rewarding
Choose own hours when relief worker
cons:
Get promised hours that do not exist, try to make you do nights and weekends after sign up.
Abusive manipulative management.
Zero people skills.
The most unprofessional company I have had the misfortune to be a part of. 
False promises, more concerned with paperwork than people.  
Staff members get away with screaming at other staff members, knowledge of health and saftety matters are below zero I have never seen risks in homes quite like it but when I eliminate the risk I’m in trouble.. 
Seriously this is one disturbing workforce go and see for yourself..

review_title: The best support provider I have worked for
pros:
Being able to offer support and guidance to staff.
To work in a person centred way
To have the knowledge that we support people to shape their lives in the way they want it.
We are well supported with team meetings and supervision
United Response has a comprehensive training schedule which includes much more than CQC mandatory training.
United Response listens to it's staff.
United Response CARES.
cons: Health and social care is changing constantly and currently facing huge changes (back payment of sleeps, remodelling teams, not commissioning for wants just needs.) This political uncertainty can make working in this sector difficult.

pros:
Able to discuss concerns with managers and have visible action taken

Caring and person centred attitude to those supported

Focus on competency and wellbeing of staff members employed

Great staff teams with shared knowledge and experience 

Forward thinking
cons:
Slow recruitment meaning strain on current staff to cover extra hours or induct agency members that may not fully suit the service

Pay levels do not change over time with years worked. I earn the same as a new employee would in the same position.

job_title: Relief Support Worker in Totnes, England
pros: i think this is a nice company, it seems to be run mostly by sweet and well meaning people, I work on a 0 hour contract and for me this works well as it gives me the freedom to work as little or as much as i want.
cons:
UR is so disorganised I have NEVER received the correct amount of money for my month's work on time! Plus it is hard to contact anyone about questions you may have, also due to a lack of organisation.
They pay no extra for anti-social hours, including christmas day!

pros: Because people we support are treated with humanity and are central to all we do. The management is there to support staff along the way and we become one big family.
cons: Sometimes people make mistakes and sometimes we don't see things eye to eye. But, if we consider a few exceptions, everyone tries to bare their part of responsabilities and make things go right for the best interest of those we support.

pros: The people who work for this company really care about the work that they do, it is a job unlike most others. People often work beyond what is required of them, not to gain greater compensation, but do ultimately help improve the life of a person we support for the better, this is a humbling experience.
cons: The compensation would be the biggest draw back, however for me, the lack of pressure and the friendly environment compensated for this in itself.
